NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF EDUCATIONAL BROADCASTERS
14 GREGORY HALL
URBANA, ILLINOIS
June 19, 1959
Mr. Marshall McLuhan
29 Wells Hill Avenue
Toronto 10, Ontario, Canada
Dear Marshall:
I am back at Iowa once again trying to adjust to working for
a living and to administrative responsibilities - neither of which
sits well on me.
I was quite interested in your last letter. I can appreciate
the problems which you are facing. First of all, though, I believe
that there may be some misunderstanding of what the Title VII people
want. I would guess that they are really asking not for the evidence
which you hope to discover but rather for statements of the problems
in researchable terms. In other words, since they have been promised
an experiment, they are probably interested in an explication of your
questions in terms of observable behavior. For example, you talk
about non-verbal factors in attitude change. Attitude is obviously
non-verbal, though researchers often use verbal statements as indi¬
cators of the presence or absence of the concept "attitude.” I would
guess they want to know what sort of indicators you plan to use if you
don't use verbal indicators. They probably want to know wfcwrt: your cri¬
teria of such concepts as "revealing character" and "coming into sharpest
focus" and "appearing most starkly," etc.
I did a paper recently in Washington for the NEA which might sug¬
gest. some approaches to you. I do not think that the particular approach
explained in the first part will help for the kind of thing you envisage,
but I do believe that the last part might. I am enclosing a copy for
whatever you might get from it. One of the problems of going about this
sort of thing systematically is the danger of stifling insight. On the
other hand, once insight is achieved, I believe that you might well try
to reflect back, as I have suggested for educators, and try to explicate
the cues or indicators which made you feel that a particular medium did
one thing more than another medium. These cues or indicators need to
be defined clearly enough (if there is to be any experimentation) for
other researchers to observe them and arrive at the same conclusions
which you have.
